div.p: A DECLARATION From his Excellencie Sir THOMAS FAIRFAX, and his Councell of WARRE: Concerning their proceedings in the propo≈øalls prepared and agreed on by the Councel of the Army, to be tendred to the Commi≈øsioners of Parliament re≈øiding in the Army, and with them to be treated on by the Commi≈øsioners of the Army: Together with The heads of the ≈øaid Propo≈øalls, containing the particulars of their de≈øires, in pur≈øuance of their former Declarations and Papers, in order to the clearing and ≈øecuring of the Rights and Liberties of the Kingdome, and the ≈øettling of a ju≈øt and la≈øting Peace.

To which are added, Some further particular de≈øires, for the removing and redre≈øsing of divers pre≈øent pre≈øsing grievances, being al≈øo compri≈øed in, or in nece≈ø≈øary pur≈øuance of their former Repre≈øentations and Papers appointed to be treated on.
¬∂ Printed at CAMBRIDGE: Anno Dom. 1647.

div.head: ¬∂ A Declaration from his Excellencie Sir Thomas Fairfax, and his Councel of Warre: Concerning the propo≈øals of the Army for ≈øettling of a Peace, and the grounds of publi≈øhing the heads thereof.
div.p:
SInce our drawing back to Reading, we have applied our ≈øelves with all diligence to frame and ha≈øten an entire body of all the particular Propo≈øals which we would tender to the Commi≈øsioners of Parliament re≈øiding with the Army, to be treated on in pur≈øuance of tho≈øe generall de≈øires expre≈øt in our former Declarations, and Papers, for ≈øecuring of the common rights and liberties, and a pre≈øent ≈øettling of the peace of the Kingdome. In which bu≈øine≈ø≈øe (notwithstanding the many interruptions and disturbances, with daily adverti≈øements of the indirect and treacherous practi≈øes and preparations of the Committee of Militia, and others, in and about the city of London, and el≈øewhere, tending to a new warre, have occa≈øioned to the diverting or retarding of our proceedings therein, yet) we have made a progre≈ø≈øe, as ≈øpeedy as the nature and weight of ≈øuch a work would admit, and having fini≈øhed the ≈øame, we have delivered in an ab≈øtract of the heads thereof unto the ≈øaid Commi≈øsioners of Parliament to be treated upon. But the late pernicious engagement ≈øet on foot in the City; and (much more) that prodigious violence done to both Hou≈øes of Parliament on Monday la≈øt, having wholy taken us off for pre≈øent,
and rendred all proceeding in the way of Treaty thereupon, merely vain and hopele≈ø≈øe, untill it ≈øhall plea≈øe God the Parliament be righted and vindicated again≈øt that violation done to it, and re≈øtored to a condition of freedome, ≈øo as unquestioned Members of it may repair together, with ≈øafety, and proceed according to their ju≈øt freedome. We have thought good in the mean time, to make this publick tender of the heads of the ≈øaid Propo≈øals to the con≈øideration of the whole Kingdome, wherein though all circumstances requi≈øite to be determined in an actuall ≈øettlement, be not ≈øo fully and perfectly expre≈øsed, as upon the Treaty intended, (if not interrupted as before) they might ≈øpeedily have been; yet all men may ≈øee and understand in the≈øe, the effect and bottome of our de≈øires, whereupon we have ≈øincerely ≈øtudied that a pre≈øent Peace might be ≈øettled, which ≈øame thing (with and after ≈øuch vindication of the Parliament as may again render it into a capacity to establi≈øh the ≈øame) we ≈øhall still faithfully endeavour to the utmo≈øt of our power, and accordingly ≈øhall expect the chearfull and hearty concurrence of all tho≈øe, who are or ≈øhall be ≈øatisfied, concerning the integrity of our intentions to the peace and welfare of the Kingdome in the≈øe our propo≈øals; or who ≈øhall (for the main) de≈øire or approve of the ≈øame things with us, in order to a ≈øettlement.

p.hi:
And to the≈øe Propo≈øals which we here fir≈øt tender, as nece≈ø≈øary to a peace, and upon which we de≈øire the ≈øeal of Peace (in the re≈øtitution of his Maje≈øty and others to their rights, and in an Act of oblivion to be pa≈øt) we cannot but adde the further expre≈ø≈øion of our de≈øires in ≈øome other particulars, which (though not
≈øo e≈øsentiall to peace, as nece≈øsary to precede to the ≈øettling of it, yet) being matters of very publick, and (most of them) of generall grievance to the Kingdome (which we every where find the outcryes of) and being contained in, or pur≈øuant of the ≈øame things expre≈ø≈øed in our former Repre≈øentation and papers, We ≈øhall de≈øire that the Parliament being ≈øet free, no time may be lo≈øt for a ≈øpeedy con≈øideration of them, ≈øo as the former things for a pre≈øent ≈øettling of Peace be not delayed thereby.

div.closer:
Colebrook, AUGUST 2. 1647.
By the appointment of his Excellency Sir Thomas Fairfax, and the Councel of Warre. Signed, Jo. Ru≈øhworth.

div.head: The Heads of the Propo≈øals, agreed upon By his Excellency Sir THOMAS FAIRFAX and the Councell of the Army, To be tendred to the Commi≈øsioners of Parliament re≈øiding in the Army, and with them to be treated on by the Commi≈øsioners of the Army.

Containing, The Particulars of their de≈øires in pur≈øuance of their former Declarations and Papers, in order to the clearing and ≈øecuring of the Rights and Liberties of the Kingdome and the ≈øettling of a ju≈øt and la≈øting Peace. To which are added ≈øome further particular De≈øires (for the removing and redre≈ø≈øing of divers pre≈øent pre≈ø≈øing grievances) being al≈øo compri≈øed in, or in nece≈ø≈øary pur≈øuance of their former Repre≈øentations and Papers appointed to be treated upon.
div.p: I. THat (the things hereafter propo≈øed being provided for by this Parliament) a certain period may by act of Parliament be ≈øet for the ending of this Parliament: (≈øuch period to be within a yeare at mo≈øt) and in the ≈øame Act, provi≈øion to be made for the ≈øucce≈ø≈øion and con≈øtitution of Parliaments in future, as followeth:

1. That Parliaments may Biennially be called and meet at a certain day, with ≈øuch provi≈øion for the certainty thereof, as in the late act was made for the Trienniall Parliaments. And what further or other provi≈øion ≈øhall be found need full by the Parliament, to reduce it to more certainty. And upon the pa≈ø≈øing of this the ≈øaid Act for Trienniall Parliaments to be repealed.

2. Each Bienniall Parliament to ≈øit an hundred and twenty dayes certain (unle≈ø≈øe adjourned or di≈ø≈øolved ≈øooner by their own con≈øent) afterwards to be adjournable or di≈ø≈øolvable by the King, and no Parliament to ≈øit pa≈øt 240. dayes from their fir≈øt meeting, or ≈øome other limited number of dayes now to be agreed on, upon the expiration whereof, each Parliament to di≈ø≈øolve of cour≈øe if not otherwi≈øe di≈ø≈øolved ≈øooner.

3. The King upon advi≈øe of the Councell of State, in the intervalls betwixt Bienniall Parliaments, to call a Parliament extraordinary, provided it meet above 70. dayes before the next Bienniall day, and be di≈ø≈øolved at lea≈øt 60. dayes before the ≈øame, ≈øo as the cour≈øe of Bienniall elections may never be interrupted.

4. That this Parliament and each ≈øucceeding Bienniall Parliament at or before the adjournment or di≈ø≈øolution thereof may appoint Committees to continue during the intervalls for ≈øuch purpo≈øes as are in any of the≈øe propo≈øalls referred unto ≈øuch Committees.

5. That the Elections of the Commons for the ≈øucceeding Parliaments may be di≈øtributed to all Counties or other parts or divi≈øions of the Kingdome, according to ≈øome rule of equality or proportion: ≈øo as all Counties may have a number of Parliament members allowed to their choice proportionable to the re≈øpective rates they bear in the common charges and burdens of the Kingdome, or according to ≈øome other rule of equality or proportion, to render the hou≈øe of Commons (as near as may be) an equall repre≈øentative of the whole: And in order thereto, that a pre≈øent con≈øideration be had to take off the elections
of Burge≈ø≈øes for poore decayed or incon≈øiderable Towns, and to give ≈øome pre≈øent addition to the number of Parliament members of great Counties that have now le≈ø≈øe then their due proportion, to bring all (at pre≈øent) as near as may be to ≈øuch rule of proportion as afore≈øaid.
6. That effectuall provi≈øion be made for future freedome of Elections and certainty of due returns.

7. That the hou≈øe of Commons alone have the power from time to time to ≈øet down further orders and rules for the ends expre≈ø≈øed in the two la≈øt precedent Articles ≈øo as to reduce the elections of members for that Hou≈øe to more and more perfection of equality in the di≈øtribution, freedome in the Election, order in the proceeding thereto, and certainty in the returns; which orders and rules (in that ca≈øe) to be as Lawes.

8. That there be a Liberty for entring di≈ø≈øents in the hou≈øe of Commons, with provi≈øion that no member be cen≈øurable for ought ≈øaid or voted in the Hou≈øe further then to exclu≈øion from that tru≈øt and that onely by the Judgement of the hou≈øe it ≈øelf.

9. That the Judiciall power or power of finall Judgement in the Lords and Commons (and their power of expo≈øition and application of Law without further appeal) may be cleared. And that no Officer of Ju≈øtice, Mini≈øter of State, or other per≈øon adjudged by them may be capable of protection or pardon from the King without their advi≈øe and con≈øent.

10. That the rights and the liberties of the Commons of England may be cleared and vindicated as to a due exemption from any Judgement, Tryall, or other proceeding again≈øt them by the Hou≈øe of Peers without the concurring judgement of the hou≈øe of Commons, As al≈øo from any other judgement ≈øentence or proceeding again≈øt them, other then by their equalls, or according to the Law of the Land.

11. The ≈øame act to provide that Grand-jury men may be
cho≈øen by and for ≈øeverall parts or divi≈øions of each County re≈øpectively in ≈øome equall way (and not remain, as now, at the di≈øcretion of an under Sheriff to be put on or off) and that ≈øuch Grand-jury men for their re≈øpective County may each A≈ø≈øize pre≈øent the names of per≈øons to be made Ju≈øtices of Peace from time to time (as the Countrey ≈øhall need, for any to be added to the Commi≈ø≈øion) and at the Summer A≈ø≈øize to pre≈øent the names of their per≈øons, out of whom the King may prick one to be Sheriff for the next year.
II. For future ≈øecurity to Parliaments and the Militia in generall, and in order thereunto that it be provided by Act of Parliament,

1. That the power of the Militia by ≈øea and land during the ≈øpace of ten years next en≈øuing, ≈øhall be ordered and di≈øpo≈øed by the Lords and Commons a≈ø≈øembled, and to be a≈ø≈øembled in the Parliament of England, or by ≈øuch per≈øons as they ≈øhall nominate and appoint for that purpo≈øe from time to time during the ≈øaid ≈øpace.

2. That the ≈øaid power ≈øhall not be ordered, di≈øpo≈øed, or exerci≈øed by the Kings Maje≈øty that now is, or by any per≈øon or per≈øons, by any authority derived from him during the ≈øaid ≈øpace, or at any time hereafter by his ≈øaid Maje≈øty without the advi≈øe and con≈øent of the ≈øaid Lords and Commons or of ≈øuch Committee or Councell in the intervalls of Parliament as they ≈øhall appoint.

3. That during the ≈øame ≈øpace of 10. years the ≈øaid Lords and Commons may by Bill or Ordinance rai≈øe and di≈øpo≈øe of what moneyes and for what forces they ≈øhall from time to time find nece≈ø≈øary, as al≈øo for the publick debts and dammages, and for all other the publick u≈øes of the Kingdome.
4. And to the end the Temporary ≈øecurity intended by the three particulars la≈øt precedent may be the better a≈ø≈øured it may therefore be provided,

That no ≈øubjects that have been in Ho≈øtility again≈øt the Parliament in the late warre ≈øhall be capable of bearing any office of Power or publick tru≈øt in the Common wealth, during the ≈øaid ≈øpace of five years without con≈øent of Parliament or of the Councell of State, or to ≈øit as members or a≈ø≈øi≈øtants of either Hou≈øes of Parliament, untill the ≈øecond Bienniall Parliament be pa≈øt.
III. For the pre≈øent form of di≈øpo≈øing the Militia in order to the peace and ≈øafety of this Kingdome and the ≈øervice of Ireland.

1. That there be Commi≈ø≈øioners for the Admiralty, with the Vice-Admiral & rear Admiral now to be agreed on with power for the forming, regulating, appointing of Officers and providing for the Navy, and for ordering the ≈øame to and in the ordinary ≈øervices of the Kingdome, and that there be a ≈øufficient provi≈øion and e≈øtabli≈øhment for the pay and maintainance thereof.
2. That there be a Generall for the Command of the land forces that are to be in pay both in England, Ireland, and Wales, both for the Field and Garri≈øon.

3. That there be Commi≈ø≈øioners in ≈øeverall Counties for the ≈øtanding Militia of the re≈øpective Counties, (con≈øi≈øting of trained Bands and Auxiliaries not in pay) with power for the proportioning, forming, regulating, training and di≈øciplining of them.

4. That there be a councell of State, with power to ≈øuperintend and direct the three ≈øeverall and particular powers of the Militia la≈øt mentioned, for the peace and ≈øafety of this Kingdome and of Ireland.

5. That the ≈øame Councell may have power as the Kings privie Councell for and in all forreign negotiations, provided that the making of warre or peace with any other Kingdome or State ≈øhall not be without advi≈øe and con≈øent of Parliament.

6. That the ≈øaid power of the Councell of State be put into the hands of tru≈øty and able per≈øons now to be agreed on, and the ≈øame per≈øons to continue in that power (≈øi bene ≈øe ge≈ø≈øerint) for a certain terme not exceeding 7. years.

7. That there be a ≈øufficient e≈øtabli≈øhment now provided for the ≈øalary forces both in England and Ireland. The e≈øtabli≈øhment to continue untill two moneths after the meeting of the fir≈øt Bienniall Parliament.

IV. That an Act be pa≈ø≈øed for the di≈øpo≈øing of the great Offices for 10. years by the Lords and Commons in Parliament, or by ≈øuch Committees as they ≈øhall appoint for that purpo≈øe in the intervalls (with ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion to the approbation of the next Parliament) and after 10. years they to nominate three, and the King out of that number to appoint one for the ≈øucce≈ø≈øion upon any vacancy.
V. That an Act be pa≈ø≈øed for re≈øtraining of any Peeres made ≈øince the 21. of May 1643. or to be hereafter made from having power to ≈øit or vote in Parliament without con≈øent of both Hou≈øes.

VI. That an Act be pa≈ø≈øed for recalling and making void all Declarations and other proceedings again≈øt the Parliament or again≈øt any that have Acted by or under their authority in the late warre, or in relation to it, and that the Ordinances for Indemnity may be confirmed.

7. That an Act be pa≈ø≈øed for making void all grants &c. under the great Seal that was conveyed away from the Parliament, ≈øince it was ≈øo conveyed away (except as in the Parliaments propo≈øition) and for making tho≈øe valid that have been or ≈øhall be pa≈ø≈øed under the great ≈øeal made by the authority of both Hou≈øes of Parliament.
VIII. That an Act be pa≈ø≈øed for the Confirmation of the treaty between the two Kingdomes of England and Scotland, and for appointing con≈øervatours of the Peace betwixt them.

9. That the Ordinance for taking away the Court of Wards, and Liveries, be confirmed by Act of Parliament; provided his Maje≈øties Revenue be not damnified therein, nor tho≈øe that la≈øt held Offices in the ≈øame, left without reparation ≈øome other way.
X. An act to declare voyd the ce≈ø≈øation of Ireland, &c. and to leave the pro≈øecution of that warre to the Lords and Commons in the Parliament of England.

XI. An Act to be pa≈ø≈øed to take away all coercive power, Authority, or juri≈ødiction of Bi≈øhops, and all other Eccle≈øia≈øtiall Officers what≈øoever, extending to any civil penalties upon any, and to repeal all Laws, whereby the Civil Magi≈øtracy hath been, or is bound, upon any Eccle≈øia≈øticall cen≈øure to proceed ex Officio, unto any civil penalty, again≈øt per≈øons ≈øo cen≈øured.

XII. That there be a repeal of all Acts, or Clau≈øes in any Acts, enjoyning the u≈øe of the Book of Common Prayer, and impo≈øing any penalties for the neglect thereof: As al≈øo of all Acts or Clau≈øes in any Act, impo≈øing any penalty for not coming to Church, or for meetings el≈øewhere, for prayer or other Religious duties, exerci≈øes, or Ordinances, and ≈øome other provi≈øion to be made for di≈øcovering of Papi≈øts, or Popi≈øh Recu≈øants, and for di≈øabling of them, and of all Je≈øuites, or Prie≈øts, from di≈øturbing the State.

XIII. That the taking of the Covenant be not enforced upon any, nor any penalties impo≈øed upon the refu≈øers, whereby men might be con≈øtrained to take it again≈øt their judgements and con≈øciences; but all Orders or Ordinances tending to that purpo≈øe to be repeald.

XIV. That (the things here before propo≈øed, being provided for ≈øettling, or ≈øecuring the Rights, Liberties, Peace, and ≈øafety of the kingdome) his Maje≈øties per≈øon, his Queen and Royall i≈ø≈øue, may be re≈øtored to a condition of ≈øafety, honour, and freedome in this Nation, without diminution to their per≈øonall Rights, or further limitation to the exerci≈øe of Regall
power, then according to the particulars aforegoing.

XV. For the matter of Compo≈øitions: Fir≈øt that a le≈ø≈øe number out of the per≈øons excepted, out of the two fir≈øt qualifications (not exceeding five for the Engli≈øh) being nominated particularly by the Parliament (who together with per≈øons in the Iri≈øh Rebellion, included in the third qualification) may be re≈øerved to the further judgement of the Parliament, as they ≈øhall find cau≈øe: All other excepted per≈øons may be remitted from the Exception, and admitted to Compo≈øition: Secondly, that the rates for all future Compo≈øitions, may be le≈ø≈øened, and limited not to exceed the ≈øeverall proportions hereafter expre≈ø≈øed, re≈øpectively, that is to ≈øay,
1. For all per≈øons formerly excepted, not above a third part.
2. For the late members of Parliament under the fir≈øt branch of the fourth qualification of the Propo≈øition, a fourth part.
3. For other members of Parliament in the ≈øecond and third branches of the ≈øame qualification, a ≈øixth part.
4. For the per≈øons nominated in the ≈øaid fourth qualification, and tho≈øe included in the 10 qualification, an eighth part.

5. For all others included in the ≈øixth qualification, a tenth part, and that reall debts either upon record, or proved by witne≈ø≈øes, be con≈øidered and abated in the valuation of their e≈øtates, in all the ca≈øes afore≈øaid.

3. That tho≈øe who ≈øhall hereafter come to compound, may not have the Covenant put upon them, as a condition, without which they may not compound, but in ca≈øe they ≈øhall not willingly take it, they may pa≈ø≈øe their Compo≈øitions without it.

4. That the per≈øons and e≈øtates of all Engli≈øh, not worth two hundred pounds in land or goods, be at liberty and di≈øcharged: And that the Kings meniall ≈øervants, that never took up arms, but onely attended his per≈øon according to their Offices, may be freed from Compo≈øitions, or to pay (at mo≈øt)
but the proportion of one years revenue, or a twentieth part.

5. That in order to the making and perfecting of Compo≈øitions, at the rates afore≈øaid, the Rents, Revenues, and other dues and profits of all ≈øeque≈øtred e≈øtates what≈øoever (except the e≈øtates of ≈øuch per≈øons, who ≈øhall be continued under exception as before) be from henceforth ≈øu≈øpended and detained in the hands of the re≈øpective Tenants, Occupants, and others, from whom they are due for the ≈øpace of ≈øix moneths following.

6. That the Faith of the Army, and other Forces of Parliament given in Articles upon ≈øurrenders to any of the Kings party, may be fully made good, and where any breach thereof ≈øhall appear to have been made, full reparation and ≈øatisfaction may be given to the per≈øons injured; and that the per≈øons offending being found out, may be compelled thereto.
